sense.name: exhale hard
sense.examples: She blew on her soup to cool it. Go blow your nose. He made a wish and blew out the candles. The whale blew again, and they were close enough to catch some of the mist.

sense.name: (cause to) be in motion due to air currents
sense.commentary: Syntax Includes: NP1[patient] BLOW PP[directional] NP1[agent] BLOW NP2[theme] PP[directional] NOTE: the direction need not be stated, but is always implied as in example 5. Includes metaphorical uses.
sense.examples: The wind blew from the west. The leaves were blowing in the wind. I blew my hair dry. The wind blew the leaves around in the yard. She blew me a kiss. The bald eagle controversy was the biggest storm to blow through the bird-watcher community.

sense.name: make a sound
sense.examples: The whistle blew. The trumpets blew. He blew the horn. No one should blow their car horn in anger.

sense.name: explode, burst or break suddenly
sense.commentary: Includes: BLOW OFF; BLOW OUT; BLOW UP Syntax Is: NP1[agent] BLOW OFF/UP/OUT NP2[concrete] (PP NP3[instrument]) NOTE: use this sense for instances where an outer structure is destroyed because of forces WITHIN that structure.
sense.examples: He blew up his garage with a botched experiment. How does a volcano blow its top? My only transportation blew out a spark plug for the fifth time. My microwave blew a fuse, and when I replaced it, it blew again. Someone's laptop just freakin blew up and started a cozy little desktop fire! The bomb blew off the roof of the building. The oil well blew out.

sense.name: spend wastefully; squander
sense.examples: He blew his inheritance on wild living. She blew her bonus money on one outrageously expensive bottle of wine.

sense.name: make a mess of; ruin or jeapardize
sense.commentary: NOTE: this sense is used for metaphorical instances of sense 4.
sense.examples: The senator admits he blew the whole campaign with that one comment. "I blew my last chance to get him back," she sobbed. Our strategy of pitting our enemies against each other just blew up. The story blew the agent's cover.

sense.name: shape by blowing
sense.commentary: Syntax Is: NP1[agent[animate]] BLOW[volitional/controlled action] NP2[concrete]
sense.examples: Only a true artisan could have blown that vase.

sense.name: provide sexual gratification through oral stimulation
sense.examples: She stopped coming there to blow the president.

sense.name: lay eggs
sense.examples: Unable to find an attested example.

sense.name: show off
sense.examples: Unable to find an attested example.

sense.name: get very angry and fly into a rage
sense.commentary: Includes: BLOW A FUSE, BLOW ONE'S STACK; BLOW UP
sense.examples: When my mother found out where I'd been, she blew her stack. When you tell him you didn't finish the report, he will blow up. She made sports page headlines when she blew a fuse over trade talks involving her hubby.

sense.name: fill with or as if with air
sense.commentary: Includes: BLOW UP Syntax Is: NP1[agent] BLOW (PP) NP2
sense.examples: We blew up 15 balloons for the party. Her face blew up from the drugs.

sense.name: exagerate or embellish
sense.examples: I'd like to have this picture blown up to a 5 x 7. The tabloid press blew up the story about the 'party boat loaded with drugs.'

sense.name: BLOW OVER: go away without lasting consequences
sense.examples: Don't worry. It will all blow over in a few days.

sense.name: surprise, outdo or impress greatly
sense.commentary: Includes: BLOW AWAY, BLOW OUT OF THE WATER
sense.examples: Her news really blew me out of the water.
